meanings.def: to want something or want to do something
examples: fancy something Fancy a drink?
I fancied a change of scene.
She didn't fancy (= did not like) the idea of going home in the dark.
fancy doing something Do you fancy going out this evening?

meanings.def: to be sexually attracted to somebody
examples: I think she fancies me.

meanings.def: to think that you are very popular, attractive or intelligent
examples: He started to chat to me and I could tell that he really fancied himself.

meanings.def: to like the idea of being something or to believe, often wrongly, that you are something
examples: fancy yourself (as) something She fancies herself (as) a serious actress.
fancy yourself + adv./prep. He fancied himself in love with me, the silly boy.

meanings.def: used to show that you are surprised or shocked by something
examples: Fancy! She's never been in a plane before.
fancy doing something Fancy meeting you here!
fancy something ‘She remembered my name after all those years.’ ‘Fancy that!’

meanings.def: to think that somebody/something will win or be successful at something, especially in a race
examples: Which horse do you fancy in the next race?
He's hoping to get the job but I don't fancy his chances.
She fancied (that) she could hear footsteps.

related: as/whenever, etc. the fancy takes you

meanings.def: unusually complicated, often in an unnecessary way; intended to impress other people
examples: a kitchen full of fancy gadgets
They added a lot of fancy footwork to the dance.
He's always using fancy legal words.

meanings.def: with a lot of decorations or bright colours
examples: fancy goods (= things sold as gifts or for decoration)
He was the fanciest dresser in the room.

meanings.def: expensive or connected with an expensive way of life
examples: fancy restaurants with fancy prices
Don't come back with any fancy ideas.

meanings.def: something that you imagine; your imagination
examples: night-time fancies that disappear in the morning
a child’s wild flights of fancy

meanings.def: a feeling that you would like to have or to do something
examples: She said she wanted a dog but it was only a passing fancy.

meanings.def: as/whenever, etc. you feel like doing something
examples: We bought a camper van so we could go away whenever the fancy took us.
She looked through the hotel advertisements until one of them caught her fancy.

meanings.def: to start liking somebody/something, often without an obvious reason
examples: He’s taken quite a fancy to his next-door neighbour.
See if any of these tickle your fancy.
If you see something that tickles your fancy, I’ll buy it for you.

idioms.idiom: as/whenever, etc. the fancy takes you
idioms.def: as/whenever, etc. you feel like doing something
examples: We bought a camper van so we could go away whenever the fancy took us.
